checks.phraseInfo: "You are like salt for the people of the world" or "As salt is for food, you are for the world." This can mean 1) "Just as salt makes food good, you must influence the people of the world so that they will be good" or 2) "Just as salt preserves food, so you will keep people from becoming totally corrupt." (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).

checks.phrase: not one jot or one tittle

checks.phraseInfo: This is a metaphor for total secrecy. Just as hands usually work together and can be said to "know" what each other is doing at all times, you should not let even those closest to you know when you are giving to the poor. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

checks.phrase: The eye is the lamp of the body
checks.phraseInfo: "like a lamp, the eye allows you to see things clearly" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Jesus compares the actions of the prophets to fruit produced by plants. Alternate translation: "by the way they act." (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

checks.phrase: Every tree that does not yield good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire
checks.phraseInfo: Jesus continues to use fruit trees as a metaphor to refer to false prophets. Here, he only states what will happen to the bad trees. checks.phrase: People who are strong in body

checks.phrase: No man puts a piece of new cloth on an old garment

(See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

checks.phrase: what did you go out to see
checks.phraseInfo: Jesus used this phrase in three rhetorical questions to cause the people to think about what kind of person John the Baptist was. It could be translated as “Did you go out to see …? Of course not!” or “Surely you did not go out to see …!” (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

checks.phrase: But what did you go out to see
checks.phraseInfo: This continues the series of rhetorical questions about John the Baptist. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

This is the start of a rhetorical question. Jesus used it to introduce a comparison between the people of that day and what children might say in the marketplace. He begins with a rhetorical question. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Jesus is mildly rebuking the Pharisees for not learning from what they read. Alternate translation: “You should learn from what you have read about.” (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"only priests were permitted to eat it" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

checks.phrase: have you not read in the law
checks.phraseInfo: "You have read the law, so you know that it says" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
“Satan's kingdom cannot stand,” or “Satan's kingdom will fall apart.” (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

checks.phrase: by whom do your followers drive them out
checks.phraseInfo: Alternate translation: "it must also be the power of Beelzebul that enables your followers to drive out demons" (or see UDB). (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

checks.phrase: who warned you to flee from the wrath that is coming
checks.phraseInfo: With this rhetorical question John was rebuking the people because they were asking him to baptize them so that God would not punish them, but they did not want to stop sinning. "You can't flee from God's wrath like this” or “Do not think that you can flee from God's wrath just by being baptized” (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

checks.phrase: what man among you is there
checks.phraseInfo: This rhetorical question means "none of you would." (See: UDB, [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

checks.phrase: he will in no way lose his reward
checks.phraseInfo: "that person will certainly receive his reward" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

checks.phrase: it is not the will of your Father in heaven that one of these little ones should perish
checks.phraseInfo: "Your Father in heaven wants all of these little ones to live" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
“in front of you” or “to go ahead of you.” The pronoun “you” is singular, because God was speaking to the Messiah in the quotation. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
The word "you" is plural, referring to the disciples.(See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

This expression, where wisdom is personified, is not used here in the sense that wisdom is put right before God but in the sense that wisdom is proved right (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]]).

checks.phrase: tomorrow will be anxious for itself
checks.phraseInfo: This personification actually refers to the person who lives "the next day"  (see UDB). (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

If your language would understand this personification to mean that the fever could think and act on its own, this can be translated as "she became better" or "Jesus healed her." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

checks.phrase: even the winds and the sea obey him
checks.phraseInfo: For people or animals to obey or disobey is not surprising, but for wind and water to obey is very surprising. This personification describes the natural elements as able to hear and respond like people. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

checks.phrase: The news about this spread into all that region
checks.phraseInfo: This personification means that the news spread because the people told it to other people. "The people of that whole region heard about it" (UDB) or "The people who saw that the girl was alive started telling everyone in the whole area about it." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

checks.phrase: it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the day of judgment than for you
checks.phraseInfo: "God will show more mercy to Tyre and Sidon in the day of judgment than to you" or "God will punish you more severely at the day of judgment than the people of Tyre and Sidon" (see UDB). The implied information is “because you did not repent and believe in me, even though you saw me do miracles.” (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

checks.phrase: it shall be easier for the land of Sodom in the day of judgment than for you
checks.phraseInfo: This can be translated “God will show more mercy to the land of Sodom in the day of judgment than to you” or “God will punish you more severely at the day of judgment than the people of Sodom” (see UDB). The implied information is “because you did not repent and believe in me, even though you saw me do miracles.” (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"I will allow you to rest from your labor and burden" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"good food seeds" or "good grain seeds." The audience probably thought that Jesus was talking about wheat. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

checks.phrase: This seed is indeed the smallest of all other seeds
checks.phraseInfo: Mustard seeds were the smallest seeds known to the original hearers. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
until the dough rose. The implied information is that the yeast and the three measures of flour were made into dough for baking. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The implied information is that the man was looking for valuable pearls that he could buy. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"they do not wash their hands in the ceremony required by our law" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"open the door for us so we can come inside" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"As they came out of Jerusalem" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
the clothing Jesus had been wearing (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

checks.phrase: A city set on a hill cannot be concealed
checks.phraseInfo: "The lights of a city on a hill cannot be hidden at night" or "Everyone sees the lights of a city on a hill" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus was referring to himself in the third person. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

checks.phrase: the Son of Man coming in his kingdom
checks.phraseInfo: Jesus was referring to himself in the third person. AT:"until they see me coming in my kingdom."  (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

checks.phrase: I desire mercy and not sacrifice
checks.phraseInfo: Sacrifices are good, but mercy is better. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"he has shallow roots" or "he allows the young plant no place for its roots" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
“becomes a large bush” (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

checks.phrase: without parables he said nothing to them
checks.phraseInfo: "he taught them nothing except by parables." Alternate translation: "everything he said to them he said in parables." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Possible meanings: 1) "for fear that they lose consciousness temporarily" or 2) "for fear that they become weak" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

Possible meanings: 1) "70 times 7" (ULB) or 2) "77 times" (UDB). If using a number would be confusing, you can say, "more times than you can count" (see UDB and [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]]).
"many of the people in the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

"forcefully remove it" or "destroy it" (see UDB). If the right eye is not specifically mentioned, you may need to translate this "pluck your eyes out." If eyes have been mentioned, you may need to translate this "pluck them out" (see UDB). (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]].)
The largest part of a tree that has been cut down, a piece of wood far too large to literally go into a person's eye. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

Though the man would have to talk to the priest when he gave the sacrifice (see UDB), Jesus wanted the man to say nothing to anyone else about what had happened. This can be translated as "do not say anything to anyone" or "do not tell anyone that I healed you." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

checks.phrase: he drove out the spirits with a word
checks.phraseInfo: This is hyperbole. Jesus could have spoken more than one word. This can be translated as "Jesus only had to speak once and the demons left the man." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This would mean a many or most of the people, not necessarily every person. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"many of the cities." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This refers to the Queen of Sheba, a Gentile kingdom. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]], [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Herod Antipas, ruler of one-fourth of Israel (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
a small town on the northwest shore of the sea of Galilee (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
sometimes called "Magdala" (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
a village (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
officials and followers of the Jewish king Herod, who was friendly to the Roman empire (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The Gadarenes were named for the town of Gadara. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
a very small seed that grows into a large plant (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
divisions of the Roman army of about six thousand soldiers (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

Foxes are animals like dogs that eat nesting birds and other small animals. If foxes are unknown in your area, use a general term for dog-like creatures or other furry animals. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"and where does he get the power to do these miracles" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

checks.phrase: that our eyes may be opened
checks.phraseInfo: AT: "we want you to make us able to see" or "we want to be able to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"received back my own gold" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

checks.phrase: five loaves of bread and two fish
checks.phraseInfo: "5 loaves of bread and 2 fish" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"7 times" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

checks.phrase: more than twelve legions of angels
checks.phraseInfo: The exact number of angels is not important. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

checks.phrase: it is good for us to be here
checks.phraseInfo: Possible meanings: 1) "it is good that we disciples are here with you, Moses, and Elijah" or 2) "it is good that you, Moses, Elijah, and we disciples are all here together" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
This does not include Jesus. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
exclusive (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
the speakers, but not the hearers (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Jesus was including the disciples. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

checks.phrase: this generation will not pass away
checks.phraseInfo: "the people living today will not all die" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This euphemism means "before they had sexual relations." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"did not have sexual relations with her" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This is a euphemism for divorce. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

checks.phrase: allow me first to go and bury my father
checks.phraseInfo: This is a polite request. Jewish custom was to bury people the same day they died, so the man's father was probably still alive and the man was using "bury" as a euphemism for caring for his father for days or even years until he died(see UDB). If the father were already dead, the man would have been asking to go away for a matter of hours. Specify that the father was or was not dead only if needed to avoid wrong meaning. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

"had a severe flow of blood." She was probably bleeding from her womb even when it was not the normal time for it. Some cultures may have a polite way of referring to this condition. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"sinful people" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This word is used here to mark a break in the main story line so the writer can give information to help the reader understand what happens beginning in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:27:17]]. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

checks.phrase: He is the King of Israel
checks.phraseInfo: The leaders do not believe Jesus is the King of Israel. (See: [[en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
"everything God has created" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

checks.phrase: from the east and the west
checks.phraseInfo: This is a merism: everywhere not east of a given point is west. This can be translated as "from everywhere" or "from far away in every direction." (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
If your language has a way of expressing the beginning of a new section in a story, use it here. (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

checks.phrase: took our sickness and bore our diseases
checks.phraseInfo: "freed people from being sick and made them well" (See: [[en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
